natural problem: Let \[g(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} 3x+6 & \quad \text{ if } x < 0 \\ 2x - 13 & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 0 \end{aligned} \right.\]Find all solutions to the equation $g(x) = 3.$
natural solution: Because $g$ is defined piecewise, we take cases. If $x < 0,$ then we have $3x + 6 = 3,$ which gives $x = -1.$ Since $-1 < 0,$ this is a valid solution. If $x \ge 0,$ then we have $2x - 13 = 3,$ which gives $x = 8.$ Since $8 \ge 0,$ this is a valid solution.
Thus, the solutions to the equation are $x = \boxed{-1, 8}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x < 0 \<longrightarrow> g x = 3 * x + 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> g x = 2 * x - 13"
and h2 : "g x = 3"
shows  "x = -1 \<or> x = 8"
a_0.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 Because $g$ is defined piecewise, we take cases. If $x < 0,$ then we have $3x + 6 = 3,$ which gives $x = -1.$ Since $-1 < 0,$ this is a valid solution. If $x \ge 0,$ then we have $2x - 13 = 3,$ which gives $x = 8.$ Since $8 \ge 0,$ this is a valid solution.
 Thus, the solutions to the equation are $x = \boxed{-1, 8}.$
 *)

shows  "x = -1 \<or> x = 8"
 proof-
